caption.text: For the news nerds: given the gridded dataset of resolution 0.75¬∞ √ó 0.75¬∞ (1, 2), I sampled 4,000 random points in the bounded 2D region using [Poisson-disc sampling](https://www.jasondavies.com/poisson-disc/), applied IDW on said sample using the input points to predict the sample's PM 2.5 readings, then used `d3.tricontour` to create a smooth surface from the sample predictions (4). I'll use this same procedure for every interpolation technique. To produce a polygon that enclose each input (2) or sampled (3) point, I used `d3.geoVoronoi` (here's a [tutorial](https://observablehq.com/@fil/d3-geo-voronoi-and-gridded-data)). *What would happen if I applied `tricontour` directly on the input values?*

description.text: Remember The New York Times's [global map of particulate pollution](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/12/02/climate/air-pollution-compare-ar-ul.html) in 2019? One thing I wish I could do is to zoom in on Vietnam. That itself is easy. What's complicated is smoothening the pixel-looking polygons that only get bigger and uglier as you zoom.

Historical geospatial research have shown [various ways](http://www.bisolutions.us/A-Brief-Introduction-to-Spatial-Interpolation.php) to do this, and I'll be testing all of them. What you're seeing is the process of interpolating via [*inverse-distance weighing*](https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/800186.810616), applied to a snapshot of particulate matter (PM 2.5) concentration at 4 AM on November 12, 2019, a time when pollution in Hanoi [reached its peak](https://e.vnexpress.net/news/life/trend/hanoi-burning-its-way-to-pollution-4033434.html).

I requested the data via Python API calls from [forecast results](https://ads.atmosphere.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/cams-global-reanalysis-eac4) by the ECMWF Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service, also the source in the Times article.

examples.title: The Woman Citizen's Wheel of Progress, 1917

description.text: I recreated a 1917 radial map that shows U.S. states' support for legislation of interest to women's suffrage organizations. Good visualizations are truly timeless!

This chart and its later versions were printed in *The Woman Citizen*, an American weekly periodical, as well as flyers in the years leading to the 1920 ratification of the 19th Amendment. You can find the original on the [Claremont Colleges Digital Library's website](https://ccdl.claremont.edu/digital/collection/p15831coll5/id/616).

The New York Times's [timeline of events](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/10/02/us/politics/trump-contact-tracing-covid.html) Donald Trump had participated in the week before he tested postive for COVID-19, on a force-directed graph.

The Times didn't include a formal dataset for this story, so I resorted to web scraping. After requesting the HTML file via Axios, I used `d3.select` instead of Cheerio, my go-to scraping library, to obtain the lists of people and meetings, since I was going to use D3 to create the graph anyway. Worked like a charm!
ProPublica's [cartogram of COVID-19 trajectory](https://projects.propublica.org/reopening-america/) across U.S. states, recreated.
To calculate the trend line in each state, I applied linear regression on daily numbers of positive tests per 100,000 people, smoothened into seven-day moving averages, for the past 14 days.
A zoomable timeline of all justices in the U.S. Supreme Court, classified by seat number.

examples.title: Fatal Police Shootings in the U.S.

description.text: An animated version of The Washington Post's [map of all fatal shootings](https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/investigations/police-shootings-database/#js-map) by on-duty police officers from Jan. 1, 2015. Orange flashes indicate new shootings each day.
This was my first attempt at Mapbox, which I absolutely loved!

examples.title: Child Opportunity Index: N.Y.C. & Long Island

description.text: A beeswarm plot tracking the distribution of child-opportunity scores across census tracts in New York City and Long Island.
The [Child Opportunity Index](http://diversitydatakids.org/) measures conditions crucial to child development in the U.S. For this visualization, I used its 2015 scores.
One of the few data visualizations that specifically tracks COVID-19's progress in Vietnam, including a bubble chart and a heat map.

This one was a doozy! Before Vietnam's Minstry of Health release its data of all confirmed cases, I had to compile mine from scratch by going through a *lot* of newspaper articles. Then, from that dataset, using Google Sheets, I created pivot tables detailing daily cases, recoveries and deaths by province, then published them as CSVs that I fetched with D3.
A line-chart matrix showing quarterly house prices, index by the first quarter of 1975, of some non-G7 countries (green) and the U.S. (orange). Can you see traces of the 2008 financial crisis?

I made this one as a tribute to FiveThirtyEight's [matrix visualization](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/trump-approval-ratings/) of Donald Trump's approval ratings compared to other presidents', using `d3.select` with `d3.cross`.

A flow chart outlining the process of creating Nate Silver's [forecast](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-primary-forecast/) for the 2020 Democratic primary, part of the 2020 presidential election in the U.S.

examples.title: The Pink, Minimalist Aesthetic Enticing Hanoi's Millennials

description.text: At the intersection between Hang Bong and Phung Hung streets, there is a bakery whose lavender armchairs look as if they are made from giant ladyfingers. It‚Äôs called Baked by Julie and, since opening last August, has constantly appeared on Instagram thanks to its predominantly pink palette, which is featured on its velour, mitten-shaped armchairs, ceramic teapots and garlanded entrance.

examples.title: For Vietnam's Millennials, Sneakers Reflect American Ideals, Self-Expression and Nostalgia

description.text: My memories of sneakers date back to when I was halfway through 7th grade, when a pair of Chuck Taylor All Star 70‚Äôs was given to me by my parents to commemorate my good end-of-semester results. The shoes felt awkward, but the sensation of having the same sneakers that the cool kids were wearing was comparable to ecstasy.
